quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When I first came to Anthropic and I was like, "Oh my God, I really love front-end engineering." And then the reason why I switched to research is because I realized, "Oh my God, Claude is getting better at front-end. Claude is getting better at coding. I think Claude can develop new apps."
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A concrete example of career strategy: move up the stack toward work that stays valuable as models rapidly automate implementation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Creative thinking and you kind of want to generate a bunch of ideas and filter through them and not just build the best product experience.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: An actionable product-team workflow: emphasize divergent idea generation followed by strong filtering, not just execution on a single “best” UX path.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think it's actually really, really hard to teach the model how to be aesthetic or really good visual design or how to be extremely creative in the way they write.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A contrarian take on durable human advantage: aesthetics and creative taste may remain harder to automate than many technical tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When you taught the model, some of the self-knowledge of you actually don't have a physical body to operate in the physical world, the model would get extremely confused.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A memorable insight about model training: aligning a model’s “self-knowledge” can be non-obvious and failure modes can be surprising.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Vanta
quotes.text: What makes Enterpret special is its ability to build and update customer-specific AI models that provide the most granular and accurate insights into your business, connect customer insights to revenue and operational data in your CRM or data warehouse to map the business impact of each customer need and prioritize confidently, and empower your entire team to easily take action on use cases like win-loss analysis, critical bug detection and identifying drivers of churn with Enterpret's AI system, Wisdom.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Enterpret)
quotes.context: A practical methodology for tying qualitative customer feedback to quantitative business impact so teams can prioritize with confidence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Vanta
quotes.text: Enterpret unifies all your customer interactions from Gong calls to Zendesk tickets to Twitter threads to app store reviews, and makes it available for analysis.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Enterpret)
quotes.context: An actionable approach to building a single source of truth for customer feedback across channels.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Vanta
quotes.text: So we started Vanta in 2018. Focused on founders, helping them start to build out their security programs and get credit for all of that hard security work with compliance certifications like SOC 2 or ISO 27001 today, we currently help over 9,000 companies, including some startup household names like Atlassian, Ramp and LangChain start and scale their security programs and ultimately build trust by automating compliance, centralizing GRC, and accelerating security reviews.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point plus a clear operating model for building trust: automate compliance, centralize GRC, and speed up security reviews.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Vanta
quotes.text: But the idea is with automation, with AI, with software, we are helping customers build trust with prospects and customers in an efficient way.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: A memorable framing that positions compliance work as a trust-building lever that can be made efficient through automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Vanta
quotes.text: And our joke, we started this compliance company so you don't have to.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: A quotable, counterintuitive positioning: outsource the pain of compliance by productizing it.

quotes.topic_title: Why model training is an art
quotes.text: Model training is more an art than a science.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive framing that sets expectations: training isn’t purely deterministic engineering, but requires judgment and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Why model training is an art
quotes.text: And in a lot of ways we, as model trainers, think a lot about data quality. It's one of the most important things in model training is like how do you ensure the highest quality data for certain interaction model behavior that you want to create?
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Actionable emphasis on data quality as the primary lever for shaping model behavior, not just scaling compute or parameters.

quotes.topic_title: Why model training is an art
quotes.text: But the way you debug models is actually very similar the way you debug software.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A practical mental model for practitioners: treat model issues like software bugs—reproduce, isolate, and iterate via targeted changes.

quotes.topic_title: Why model training is an art
quotes.text: And so the model would get extremely confused about whether it can set an alarm, but it doesn't have a body in the physical world.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Concrete example of conflicting training signals (capability via function calls vs. “no body” constraints) producing inconsistent behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Why model training is an art
quotes.text: And so there is always a balance trade off between how do you make the model to be more helpful for users, but also not being harmful in other scenarios.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A core operating principle for alignment: optimizing helpfulness and safety is inherently a tradeoff that must be managed deliberately.

quotes.topic_title: Data walls, post-training, and synthetic data
quotes.text: But what actually the model is learning during that process is actually how do you compress the compression algorithm here? The model learns to compress a lot of knowledge and it learns how to model the world.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Reframes pretraining as learning a world-model via compression, a useful mental model for thinking about what scales (and what doesn’t).

quotes.topic_title: Data walls, post-training, and synthetic data
quotes.text: But I think what's happening right now with new paradigm of o1 series is that the scaling in post-training itself is not hitting the wall.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Challenges the “data wall” narrative by pointing to post-training scaling as the next lever practitioners should focus on.

quotes.topic_title: Data walls, post-training, and synthetic data
quotes.text: we went from raw data sets from pre-trained models to infinite amount of tasks that you can teach the model in the post-training world via reinforcement learning.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Offers an actionable methodology shift: move from collecting more raw text to defining/teaching more tasks via RL.

quotes.topic_title: Data walls, post-training, and synthetic data
quotes.text: So I think the bottleneck is actually in evaluations that we don't have all the frontier, like evals like, I don't know, GPQA, which is a Google-proof question answering, PhD level intelligence.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Highlights eval design as the limiting factor once benchmarks saturate—guidance for teams investing in measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Data walls, post-training, and synthetic data
quotes.text: So this is an active research area is how can you synthetically construct new tasks with models to learn.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Points to a practical direction for synthetic data: generating/curating new tasks rather than just more generic training text.

quotes.topic_title: How Canvas was trained with synthetic behaviors
quotes.text: And it's really hard to kind of like figure out how people... when you deploy a product, how people would be able to use it. And so the way you synthetically train the model is physically figuring out what are the most core behaviors that you wanted the product feature to do.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A practical methodology: define the core behaviors you want in-product, then use synthetic training data to teach those behaviors before/alongside deployment.

quotes.topic_title: How Canvas was trained with synthetic behaviors
quotes.text: And for Canvas, for example, it came down to three main behaviors. It was how do you trigger Canvas for prompts like, "Write me a long essay," when the user intention is mostly iterating over long documents? Or, "Write me a piece of code," or when to not trigger Canvas for prompts like, "Can you tell me more about President..." I don't know, some of the general questions. So you don't want to trigger Canvas because the user intention is mostly getting answer, not necessarily iterate over the long document.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A concrete framework for product behavior design: explicitly train a decision boundary for when a feature should activate vs stay out of the way, based on user intent.

quotes.topic_title: How Canvas was trained with synthetic behaviors
quotes.text: So one of the behaviors that we taught the model is actually have some agency and autonomy to literally go to the document and select specific sections and either delete it or edit, so highlight it and rewrite certain sections.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: An actionable approach to editing agents: train explicit “document operations” (select/delete/rewrite) rather than only generating new text.

quotes.topic_title: How Canvas was trained with synthetic behaviors
quotes.text: And when we first launched the model, we would bias the model towards more rewrites because we saw the quality of the rewrites were much higher. But over time you are shifting based on user feedback and what you're learning from iterative deployment.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product tactic: start with full rewrites for quality, then move toward targeted edits as you learn from real usage.

quotes.topic_title: How Canvas was trained with synthetic behaviors
quotes.text: And it all came down to measuring progress via very robust evals.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A crisp operating principle: synthetic training only works if you can reliably measure behavior improvements with strong evaluations.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day work: prompting, debugging, and roles
quotes.text: Actually, I think I learned this so much from Anthropic, is people spend so much time prompting models and where quality's a really bad batch all the time, and you actually get a lot of new ideas of how do you make the model better?
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology: heavy prompting to surface failure modes and generate concrete improvement ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day work: prompting, debugging, and roles
quotes.text: It's like, "This response is kind of weird. Why's it doing this?" And you start debugging or something, or you start figuring out new methods of how do you teach the model to respond in the different way, have better personality, let's say.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Gives an actionable loop—notice odd outputs, ask why, debug, and turn observations into training methods.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day work: prompting, debugging, and roles
quotes.text: I was running code, training models, write evals, working with PMs and designers to learn, teach them how to even think about evaluation.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Emphasizes that building AI products includes cross-functional enablement—teaching stakeholders how to evaluate model behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day work: prompting, debugging, and roles
quotes.text: I'm still doing IC research code up to 4:00 PM, although.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A concrete example of balancing management/mentorship with hands-on research work.

quotes.topic_title: Evals in product development workflows
quotes.text: But we built out some of the deterministic evaluations that is like, "Okay, if the user says 7:00 PM, the model should say 7:00 PM." So if you can have deterministic evals whether it's pass or fail.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Concrete example of turning fuzzy model behavior into simple pass/fail checks that product teams can operationalize.

quotes.topic_title: Evals in product development workflows
quotes.text: And the way it works is all the... Sometimes I ask product managers to just go create a double sheet, have different tabs and what's the current behavior, what's the ideal behavior and why, and some notes.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Practical workflow artifact (a spreadsheet structure) that teams can use to define and track “correct” behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Evals in product development workflows
quotes.text: And sometimes they usually use it with evals, sometimes we use it for training. Because if you give the spreadsheet to o1 model, it can probably figure out how to teach itself a good behavior.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive idea that the same eval documentation can double as training input, tightening the build-measure loop.

quotes.topic_title: Evals in product development workflows
quotes.text: And then you can have continuous win rates. And as you develop new models it should always win over the previous models.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Simple methodology for human preference evals: track win rates and require each new model to beat the last.

quotes.topic_title: Evals in product development workflows
quotes.text: And then that's when it clicked to me, and also one of the blog posts a long time ago, it clicked on me prompting is a new way of product development or prototyping for designers and for product managers.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Reframes prompting as a core product development/prototyping tool, not just a way to interact with models.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting as prototyping and micro-experiences
quotes.text: I would say prompting is also a way to prototype new product ideas.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Frames prompting as a practical prototyping medium for product teams, not just a way to “talk to” models.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting as prototyping and micro-experiences
quotes.text: it clicked on me prompting is a new way of product development or prototyping for designers and for product managers.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A clear mental model shift: prompting can function like a new product development workflow for PMs/designers.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting as prototyping and micro-experiences
quotes.text: For example, one of the features that I want to do is have a personalized starter prompts. So whenever you come to Claude, it should recommend you starter prompts based on what your interests are. And so you can literally do it prompting for that.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Concrete, actionable example of using prompting to prototype personalization and onboarding UX quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting as prototyping and micro-experiences
quotes.text: Another feature was generating titles for the conversations. It's a very small micro experience but I'm really proud of. The way we did that was we took five latest conversation from the model, asked the model, "What's the style of the user?" And then for the next new conversation, the generated title will be of the same style. It's just like really little micro experiences like this.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Specific methodology for creating “micro-experiences” by inferring user style from recent history and matching it in UI outputs.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships tools like Tasks
quotes.text: But the way it comes usually operationally... Yeah, size is like a prototype, literally prompted prototype of how you would want the model to behave.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A practical methodology: start new AI features as a prompted prototype that specifies desired model behavior before engineering.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships tools like Tasks
quotes.text: And then it's mostly like developing JSON schema.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete implementation step: translating a product idea into a tool schema the model can reliably fill.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships tools like Tasks
quotes.text: And then usually with staffing is mostly a product manager, model designer, actual product designer, a couple of researchers and a bunch of applied engineers.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A reusable team composition template for shipping model-powered product features cross-functionally.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships tools like Tasks
quotes.text: And the reason why I really love relying purely on synthetic data instead of collecting data from humans is because it's much more scalable, it's cheap, less than half.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive data strategy: prefer synthetic data over human collection for speed and cost at scale.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships tools like Tasks
quotes.text: And when you launch the beta feature, you learn so much from the users that you can... All your synthetic sets can be shifted in the distribution and how the users behave on the product behavior.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: An iteration loop: use beta user behavior to reweight/shift synthetic datasets to match real-world usage and improve the product.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Loom
quotes.text: Record a Loom and send it out with just a link to gather feedback, add context or share an update.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Loom)
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable workflow for async communication that replaces long emails and speeds up feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Loom
quotes.text: So now you can delete that novel link email that you were writing.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Loom)
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that encourages switching from verbose written updates to faster, clearer video messages.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Loom
quotes.text: Loom can help you have fewer meetings and make the meetings that you do have much more productive.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Loom)
quotes.context: A practical operating principle: push context-sharing async to reduce meeting load and improve the remaining sync time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Loom
quotes.text: Meetings start with everyone on the same page and end early. Problem solved, time saved.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Loom)
quotes.context: A clear outcome metric for async prep: alignment upfront leads to shorter meetings and reclaimed time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Loom
quotes.text: We know that everyone isn't a one-take wonder when it comes to recording videos. So Loom comes with easy editing and AI features to help you record once and get back to the work that counts.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Loom)
quotes.context: Normalizes imperfection and offers a process (edit + AI assist) that lowers the barrier to adopting async video updates.

quotes.topic_title: Researchers vs model designers at OpenAI
quotes.text: And it's more about developing new methods, understanding those methods under a variety of circumstances.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A crisp definition of longer-horizon research as method development plus stress-testing across conditions, not just shipping features.

quotes.topic_title: Researchers vs model designers at OpenAI
quotes.text: So basically developing methods, you need to follow very similar recipe of building evals but it's much more sophisticated evals.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable methodology: treat research like product work, but upgrade the evaluation rigor and sophistication.

quotes.topic_title: Researchers vs model designers at OpenAI
quotes.text: You want to have outer distribution or if you want to measure generalization, you need to capture that.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A practical reminder that measuring generalization requires explicit out-of-distribution evaluation, not just in-distribution metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Researchers vs model designers at OpenAI
quotes.text: If we talk about synthetic data, one of the hardest things about synthetic data is how do you make it more diverse? Diversity in synthetic data is one of the most important questions right now.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Points to a concrete, high-leverage research bottleneck practitioners can prioritize when using synthetic data.

quotes.topic_title: Researchers vs model designers at OpenAI
quotes.text: I feel like it's always about you work on this new method and you have signs of life that it's working, either you think of how do you make it more general or you think of how do you make it very useful? And this is how the longer-term projects become more medium, short-term project.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Provides a roadmap for translating exploratory research into product impact: validate “signs of life,” then push toward generality or usefulness to shorten the horizon.

quotes.topic_title: How work changes as intelligence gets cheaper
quotes.text: So, yes, so basically there are trends that are going on. The first trend is the cost of reasoning and intelligence is drastically going down.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A clear macro-trend framing that practitioners can use to anticipate which tasks and products will be disrupted as “intelligence” becomes cheaper.

quotes.topic_title: How work changes as intelligence gets cheaper
quotes.text: But the cost of intelligence is going down because it becomes that much cheaper. Small models are becoming even smarter than large models and that's because of the distillation research.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive takeaway for builders: don’t assume bigger models win—distilled small models can outperform and change deployment economics.

quotes.topic_title: How work changes as intelligence gets cheaper
quotes.text: This happened with Claude 3 Haiku. I was working with the training on the Claude 3 Haiku and I realized it was much smarter than Claude 2, which was way bigger, lots [inaudible 00:39:08].
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A concrete example supporting the “small can be smarter” claim, useful for teams deciding between model sizes and cost/performance tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: How work changes as intelligence gets cheaper
quotes.text: Builders and developers will have much better access to AI, but also it means all the work that has been bottlenecked by intelligence will be unblocked.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A practical lens for prioritization: look for workflows constrained by expert reasoning and redesign them assuming abundant intelligence.

quotes.topic_title: How work changes as intelligence gets cheaper
quotes.text: I guess like scientific research, I think it's the dream of any AI research is to automate AI research. It's kind of scary, I'd say, which makes me think that people management will stay. It's one of the hardest thing to... Emotional intelligence with the models, creativity in itself is one of the hardest things.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Actionable career/product guidance: differentiate around human-centric skills (management, emotional intelligence, creativity) that remain hard to automate.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills and creativity as durable advantages
quotes.text: Yeah, I think creative thinking. You want to generate a bunch of ideas and filter through them and not just build the best product experience. Listening. You want to build something that the most general model will not replace you.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on durable product-team advantages: idea generation + filtering, deep user listening, and differentiation from general-purpose models.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills and creativity as durable advantages
quotes.text: The mode is more in whether you listen to them, whether you can rapidly iterate. The mode is in here.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: competitive advantage shifts from the model to the feedback loop—listening and iteration speed.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills and creativity as durable advantages
quotes.text: So it's like it doesn't necessarily matter whether the model is good or not, good right now, but you can build product ideas such that by the time the models will be really good, it'll work really well.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Contrarian product strategy: design products for where model capability is headed, not where it is today.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills and creativity as durable advantages
quotes.text: Actually, AI research progress is bottlenecked by management, research management. It's because you have constrained set of compute and you need to allocate the compute to the research paths that you feel the most convinced about.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A concrete bottleneck framing: progress depends on prioritization and compute allocation decisions, not just algorithms.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills and creativity as durable advantages
quotes.text: I think it's actually a really, really hard to teach the model how to be aesthetic or do really good visual design or how to be extremely creative in the way they write. I still think ChatGPT kind of sucks at writing and that's because it's bottlenecked by this creative reasoning.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive claim that high-taste aesthetics and truly creative writing remain hard for models, pointing practitioners toward durable human strengths.

quotes.topic_title: AI strategy, self-improvement, and organizational scaling
quotes.text: For Canvas right now, it would be very cool for the model just aggregate all the feedback from users, summarize me the top five most painful flows on user experiences.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Concrete, actionable example of using AI to turn qualitative user feedback into prioritized product strategy inputs.

quotes.topic_title: AI strategy, self-improvement, and organizational scaling
quotes.text: It's like if you have user feedback from this source, but you also have an internal dashboard with metrics and then you have other feedback or input and then it can create a plan for you, recommendations even.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: A practical mental model for AI-driven strategy: connect disparate inputs (qual + quant) to generate recommendations.

quotes.topic_title: AI strategy, self-improvement, and organizational scaling
quotes.text: Ideally the model would be able to suggest ideas, new ideas, or iterate on the experimental given the empirical results of the previous experiments like how do you come up with new ideas or the methods?
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Methodology for accelerating R&D: use AI to close the loop between experimental results and next-iteration hypotheses.

quotes.topic_title: AI strategy, self-improvement, and organizational scaling
quotes.text: It's like how do you organize research teams or generally teams combined... Compose teams such that they will be at their maximally succeed or at the maximal performance of what can possibly... We can literally create the next generation of computers. It's just the matter of conviction and the way you manage through that.
quotes.speaker: Karina Nguyen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive emphasis that management and team composition—not just technical breakthroughs—can be the limiting factor in frontier progress.

quotes.topic_title: AI strategy, self-improvement, and organizational scaling
quotes.text: I think you're basically building this thing and not efficiently doing it is limiting the potential of the human species right now.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable framing that operational efficiency in AI labs is a high-leverage constraint with outsized societal impact.
